content.question: Week 5 - Solution for Google Places API Text Search using where.data

definition.value:
For now using the dr-chuck.net API it doesn't work adding your own place, but you get the assignment working.----------Adding your own place, tested and works.Because Google changed the APIs, the where.data of place names doesn't work any more. It's fairly simple.
  • Get a Google Places API Key.
    • To use existing where.data, it's the Places API Text Search, the parameter is query, instead of address.
  • serviceurl = "https://maps.googleapis.com/maps/api/place/textsearch/json?"
    • Copy where.data to where.data.short , delete all but 10 lines it's easier to test this way, change the filename in the open(). Add your 1 place at the top. Remember to delete geodata.sqlite between runs.Reinstate the SSL line for https,
  • scontext = ssl.SSLContext(ssl.PROTOCOL_TLSv1)
  • #scontext = None
    • I left the address variable as is, updated parameter, fewer changes
  • url = serviceurl + urllib.urlencode({"key":key, "query": address})
    • Up to this point geodata.sqlite and where.js are written. I also added a few lines to write str(js) to a file and that's all working.For the key, I created a file using these noteshttps://www.coursera.org/learn/python-databases/discussions/all/threads/1nbP4dFIEeaIhQofVhmyRg

content.question: Update 13 Jan - Hide Google API key 1) in a file, 2) in screenshots

definition.value: Hide key in a 2nd file, so it's not in the main code. Normally you wouldn't make it as obvious by using key, api, as an example I have.A) Create a file, named something like geocodeapi.py, it has 1 line, initialize apikey.B) Add 2 lines to assignment code, import the key from the file aboveA) apikey = "..insert key string.." B) import geocodeapi key = geocodeapi.apikey B) Alternative version. 1 line from geocodeapi import apikey as key

The link to the Student Curated Notes is no longer available. It has been discontinued by Coursera. Dr. Chuck is providing a direct link to the archive of the Wiki site (read-only copy) here:https://online.dr-chuck.com/wiki/index.php/Pythonlearn:MainPlease be aware that since this is an archive of a MediaWiki site some of the links might be broken.

content.question: Course Home page and Time estimates

definition.value: Some of you may have noticed that the format for the Course Home page (link on the left) has changed. That page now contains all the information concerning the required readings, lecture videos, quizzes, assignments, student wiki resources, as well as optional assignments and additional videos for all 5 weeks of the course. You will also notice some numbers that represent time estimates concerning the length of time required to complete all of the course materials. Please bear in mind that the numbers are only estimates and you should not view them in absolute terms. The student body is made up of people with different skill levels and learning styles. Some will move through the materials at a rapid rate, others require more time. Every student will move at a different pace. For students who are new to programming the time estimates represent a minimum level of involvement. Expect to spend at least the amount of time suggested on the page. Some will require a lot more time. You can click on the links on the Course Home page in order to access all the materials. When you are done with a particular segment scroll down to the bottom of that page and click on the Mark as completed blue tab.

content.question: "Data is Incorrect" Error Message in Counting Email in a Database assignment

definition.value:
It appears that for every cohort there have been many posts about the "Data is Incorrect" error message for the Counting Email in a Database assignment. That error message can appear for a number of different reasons but I would like to point out the most common ones that have resulted in the rejection of the uploaded file:
  • Make sure that you remove the whitespace including the newline character. That can be accomplished in more than one way using appropriate string methods. Of course you only need to pick one way to do it.
  • Make sure that you follow the exact specifications on the assignment page. That includes using the exact table and column names. Do not use different names for the columns or the grader won't accept your answer.

Do…
  • Use clear subject titles
  • Search the forum and check the pinned posts first to see if your question has already been answered
  • Post in the correct subforum for your topic
  • Use separate posts for separate questions
    • Don’t…
  • Change the subject. Start a new thread instead.
  • Ask the same question in more than one place
  • Post code for graded assignments
  • Promote products that are not related to the course
  • Request personal information from other students

content.question: I solved the "data is incorrect" problem!

definition.value: <co-content><text>at first I thought my data is right, because there is no extra @, no space and the biggest count is 536, total 21 domains ....</text><text>but then I realised that my domain are like 'gmail.co' 'media.berkeley.ed' 'umich.ed' , see the problem? </text><text>so I changed my code, original:  (6.10 of the book)</text><text>data = line.strip()</text><text>atpos = data.find('@')</text><text>sppos = data.find(' ', atpos)</text><text>    org = data[atpos+1:sppos]</text><text>after chaning:</text><text>data = line.strip()</text><text>    atpos = data.find('@')</text><text>    org = data[atpos+1:]</text><text/><text>Hopt it helps</text></co-content>

content.question: Has anyone else found any useful tools like these?

definition.value: Only found this today http://ondras.zarovi.cz/sql/demo/ it's a simple SQL designer that lets you build your tables/fields and foreign key connections visually, then lets you output the schema as an SQL script . This web framework http://web2py.com/ is the easiest way to get an interactive web site up and running that I have found. I played with it about a year ago but didn't know enough about python and sql to get to grips with it. That has all changed now (thanks to this and other online courses) and I am busy building a little web enabled timesheet app with it. The framework is written in python and by default uses sqlite database so it's a nice follow on from this course if you want to get a web page up really quickly that has tables and forms for data input. The creator Massimo Di Pierro has tutorials up on youtube (search for web2py). It also has an embedded SQL designer http://www.web2py.com/sqldesigner like the one above which is not working properly for me but maybe it will for you.

content.question: Passed grader but had blank table entries and weird id sequences...

definition.value: My code passed on submission to the grader but on viewing the tables in the browser I didn't like what I saw, Artist, Genre and Album had multiple blank entries in their respective tables, also (as happened in one of the videos with Dr Chuck) the id sequence had gaps but he passed over it and it left the question 'why?' in my mind. I corrected the 'blank' entries problem by adding conditions before each "INSERT OR IGNORE" e.g. for Artist name insertion... if artist: cur.execute('''INSERT OR IGNORE INTO Artist (name) VALUES ( ? )''', ( artist, ) ) ...Now there are no blank entries and the tables certainly look much cleaner. However there was still the niggle that the id sequences in each table were not contiguous... Artist: 55 entries => id_seq from1 to 349 Album: 42 entries => id_seq 1 to 402 Genre: 26 entries => id_seq 1 to 303Track: 376 entries => is_seq 1 to 404 (much cleaner/closer to 1:1)(Note: I insert a record 'Unknown' before Inserting the xml data into to each table Album, Artist and Genre each 'Unknown' ends up with .id = 1 )So further digging in the sqLite docs here I found this... "Note that "monotonically increasing" does not imply that the ROWID always increases by exactly one. One is the usual increment. However, if an insert fails due to (for example) a uniqueness constraint, the ROWID of the failed insertion attempt might not be reused on subsequent inserts, resulting in gaps in the ROWID sequence. AUTOINCREMENT guarantees that automatically chosen ROWIDs will be increasing but not that they will be sequential."Now I can relax. It probably explains why many 3rd party examples of sqLite table builds seem to include their own contiguous id sequence number in their inserts.

<co-content><text>I got confused with the SQL statements and I found that it helped to draw the database schema diagram shown in the "Representing a Data Model in Tables" lecture. I used Powerpoint because I can't draw, but pencil and paper would be fine too.</text></co-content>

<co-content><text>Can someone help me with this error.</text><text/></co-content>

Dear all,In the videos Professor Severeance used the storage class VARCHAR(128) in his schema and went on to say that by passing a maximum number of allowed digits for the attribute, the database could be more efficiently constructed.However, as is pointed out on https://www.sqlite.org/datatype3.html, the VARCHAR class is not part of SQLite 3, and is grouped into the class TEXT.(In the latest version of SQLite Browser for 64 bit Windows, I can not even see the character class in the "Browse data" tab at all, very unlike the case in Professor Severance's videos.)Do you think it would be a good idea to mention the discrepancy between what is shown in the videos, and what you get when using SQLite 3?When I generated an entry with a "VARCHAR(128)" attribute, I was unable to break it by trying to create an entry with more than 128 characters, as expected in the light of the sqlite.org link above.I see that there is value in teaching VARCHAR(), if people use other systems than SQLite in the future, but wouldn't it be good to comment on that it does not exist in SQLite 3?Regards, KarlPS: I liked the last question of the first quiz of Week 2. It encourages one to think just a little bit.
